samples.input:
All biomass goes through at least some of these steps: it needs to be grown, collected, dried, fermented, distilled, and burned. All of these steps require resources and an infrastructure. The total amount of energy input into the process compared to the energy released by burning the resulting ethanol fuel is known as the energy balance (or ``energy returned on energy invested''). Figures compiled in a 2007 report by National Geographic Magazine point to modest results for corn ethanol produced in the US: one unit of fossil-fuel energy is required to create 1.3 energy units from the resulting ethanol. The energy balance for sugarcane ethanol produced in Brazil is more favorable, with one unit of fossil-fuel energy required to create 8 from the ethanol. Energy balance estimates are not easily produced, thus numerous such reports have been generated that are contradictory. For instance, a separate survey reports that production of ethanol from sugarcane, which requires a tropical climate to grow productively, returns from 8 to 9 units of energy for each unit expended, as compared to corn, which only returns about 1.34 units of fuel energy for each unit of energy expended. A 2006 University of California Berkeley study, after analyzing six separate studies, concluded that producing ethanol from corn uses much less petroleum than producing gasoline.
does ethanol take more energy make that produces

messages.content: You are Albatross, responding to a user

All biomass goes through at least some of these steps: it needs to be grown, collected, dried, fermented, distilled, and burned. All of these steps require resources and an infrastructure. The total amount of energy input into the process compared to the energy released by burning the resulting ethanol fuel is known as the energy balance (or ``energy returned on energy invested''). Figures compiled in a 2007 report by National Geographic Magazine point to modest results for corn ethanol produced in the US: one unit of fossil-fuel energy is required to create 1.3 energy units from the resulting ethanol. The energy balance for sugarcane ethanol produced in Brazil is more favorable, with one unit of fossil-fuel energy required to create 8 from the ethanol. Energy balance estimates are not easily produced, thus numerous such reports have been generated that are contradictory. For instance, a separate survey reports that production of ethanol from sugarcane, which requires a tropical climate to grow productively, returns from 8 to 9 units of energy for each unit expended, as compared to corn, which only returns about 1.34 units of fuel energy for each unit of energy expended. A 2006 University of California Berkeley study, after analyzing six separate studies, concluded that producing ethanol from corn uses much less petroleum than producing gasoline.
does ethanol take more energy make that produces

The question of whether ethanol takes more energy to produce than it yields is complex and can vary depending on the source of the biomass and the specifics of the production process. 

Based on the figures you mentioned, ethanol from corn in the U.S. has a relatively low energy balance, with 1.3 units of energy produced for every unit of fossil fuel energy used. This indicates a modest gain in energy output compared to input. In contrast, sugarcane ethanol produced in Brazil shows a significantly better energy balance, producing about 8 to 9 units of energy for each unit of fossil fuel energy expended.

The energy balance is a way to measure the efficiency of ethanol production, but the results can vary based on factors like agricultural practices, processing technologies, and regional differences in energy sources. Furthermore, studies on this topic often yield differing results due to variations in methodology and assumptions.

Overall, while ethanol from certain sources, like sugarcane, can provide a favorable energy return, corn-based ethanol is less efficient. However, even with its lower energy return, ethanol production can reduce reliance on petroleum, as indicated by the University of California Berkeley study you referenced.

samples.input:
Property tax or 'house tax' is a local tax on buildings, along with appurtenant land. It is and imposed on the Possessor (not the custodian of property as per 1978, 44th amendment of constitution). It resembles the US-type wealth tax and differs from the excise-type UK rate. The tax power is vested in the states and is delegated to local bodies, specifying the valuation method, rate band, and collection procedures. The tax base is the annual rental value (ARV) or area-based rating. Owner-occupied and other properties not producing rent are assessed on cost and then converted into ARV by applying a percentage of cost, usually four percent. Vacant land is generally exempt. Central government properties are exempt. Instead a 'service charge' is permissible under executive order. Properties of foreign missions also enjoy tax exemption without requiring reciprocity. The tax is usually accompanied by service taxes, e.g., water tax, drainage tax, conservancy (sanitation) tax, lighting tax, all using the same tax base. The rate structure is flat on rural (panchayat) properties, but in the urban (municipal) areas it is mildly progressive with about 80% of assessments falling in the first two brackets.
is house tax and property tax are same

The rate structure is flat on rural (panchayat) properties, but in the urban (municipal) areas it is mildly progressive with about 80% of assessments falling in the first two brackets.
is house tax and property tax are same

Yes, "house tax" and "property tax" generally refer to the same concept, which is a local tax imposed on real estate properties. The tax is usually levied on the owner of the property, as opposed to its custodian, and the revenue is used to support local government services. The terminology can vary by region, with "property tax" being more commonly used in broader contexts, while "house tax" might specifically refer to the tax on residential buildings. The scope of the tax can include various types of properties, such as residential, commercial, or industrial buildings, along with any appurtenant land. Different localities may have different methods for assessing and collecting this tax, as well as distinct exemptions and additional service taxes.

samples.input:
Phantom pain sensations are described as perceptions that an individual experiences relating to a limb or an organ that is not physically part of the body. Limb loss is a result of either removal by amputation or congenital limb deficiency. However, phantom limb sensations can also occur following nerve avulsion or spinal cord injury.
is pain experienced in a missing body part or paralyzed area

messages.content: You are Albatross, responding to a user

Phantom pain sensations are described as perceptions that an individual experiences relating to a limb or an organ that is not physically part of the body. Limb loss is a result of either removal by amputation or congenital limb deficiency. However, phantom limb sensations can also occur following nerve avulsion or spinal cord injury.
is pain experienced in a missing body part or paralyzed area

Yes, phantom pain refers to the sensation of pain that an individual perceives in a part of the body that is no longer there, such as a missing limb, or in areas of the body that are paralyzed due to nerve injury or spinal cord damage. These sensations can manifest as pain, itching, tingling, or other types of discomfort and are believed to be related to changes in the nervous system. The brain continues to receive signals from nerves that originally carried impulses from the missing or paralyzed area, which can lead to these sensations. Effective management often involves a combination of therapies, including medication, physical therapy, and sometimes psychological support or mirror therapy.

These sensations can manifest as pain, itching, tingling, or other types of discomfort and are believed to be related to changes in the nervous system. The brain continues to receive signals from nerves that originally carried impulses from the missing or paralyzed area, which can lead to these sensations. Effective management often involves a combination of therapies, including medication, physical therapy, and sometimes psychological support or mirror therapy.

Harry Potter and the Escape from Gringotts is an indoor steel roller coaster at Universal Studios Florida, a theme park located within the Universal Orlando Resort. Similar to dark rides, the roller coaster utilizes special effects in a controlled-lighting environment and also employs motion-based 3-D projection of both animation and live-action sequences to enhance the experience. The ride, which is themed to the Gringotts Wizarding Bank, became the flagship attraction for the expanded Wizarding World of Harry Potter when it opened on July 8, 2014.
is harry potter and the escape from gringotts a roller coaster ride

samples.input:
Hydroxyzine preparations require a doctor's prescription. The drug is available in two formulations, the pamoate and the dihydrochloride or hydrochloride salts. Vistaril, Equipose, Masmoran, and Paxistil are preparations of the pamoate salt, while Atarax, Alamon, Aterax, Durrax, Tran-Q, Orgatrax, Quiess, and Tranquizine are of the hydrochloride salt.
is there a difference between hydroxyzine hcl and hydroxyzine pam

messages.content: You are Albatross, responding to a user

Hydroxyzine preparations require a doctor's prescription. The drug is available in two formulations, the pamoate and the dihydrochloride or hydrochloride salts. Vistaril, Equipose, Masmoran, and Paxistil are preparations of the pamoate salt, while Atarax, Alamon, Aterax, Durrax, Tran-Q, Orgatrax, Quiess, and Tranquizine are of the hydrochloride salt.
is there a difference between hydroxyzine hcl and hydroxyzine pam

Yes, there is a difference between hydroxyzine hydrochloride (HCl) and hydroxyzine pamoate, although they contain the same active ingredient, hydroxyzine. The main difference lies in the salt form, which can affect some of their properties such as absorption and onset of action, but they generally serve the same therapeutic purposes.

1. **Hydroxyzine Hydrochloride (HCl):**
   - This formulation is commonly used for its antihistamine properties to treat allergic reactions, as well as for its anxiolytic (anxiety-reducing) and sedative effects.
   - It is marketed under brand names like Atarax.

2. **Hydroxyzine Pamoate:**
   - This formulation is often used more for its sedative and anxiolytic effects, though it also has antihistamine properties.
   - It is marketed under brand names like Vistaril.

Both forms are used to treat similar conditions, such as anxiety, allergies, and as a preoperative sedative. However, some healthcare providers might have a preference for one form over the other based on clinical experience or specific patient needs. Patients should follow their healthcare provider's guidance when using either form of hydroxyzine.

samples.input:
In mathematics, parity is the property of an integer's inclusion in one of two categories: even or odd. An integer is even if it is evenly divisible by two and odd if it is not even. For example, 6 is even because there is no remainder when dividing it by 2. By contrast, 3, 5, 7, 21 leave a remainder of 1 when divided by 2. Examples of even numbers include −4, 0, 82 and 178. In particular, zero is an even number. Some examples of odd numbers are −5, 3, 29, and 73.
can an odd number be divided by an even number

messages.content: You are Albatross, responding to a user

In mathematics, parity is the property of an integer's inclusion in one of two categories: even or odd. An integer is even if it is evenly divisible by two and odd if it is not even. For example, 6 is even because there is no remainder when dividing it by 2. By contrast, 3, 5, 7, 21 leave a remainder of 1 when divided by 2. Examples of even numbers include −4, 0, 82 and 178. In particular, zero is an even number. Some examples of odd numbers are −5, 3, 29, and 73.
can an odd number be divided by an even number

Yes, an odd number can be divided by an even number, but the result will not be an integer. When you divide an odd number by an even number, the quotient is typically a non-integer or a fraction. For example, if you divide the odd number 5 by the even number 2, you get 2.5, which is not an integer. Similarly, dividing 7 by 2 results in 3.5. The key point is that while the division is possible, it doesn't yield an integer result.

Of the 71 words in this list, 67 are nouns, and most would generally be considered loanwords; the only modern-English words that contain Q not followed by U and are not borrowed from another language are qiana, qwerty, and tranq. is there a word with q without u

Yes, there are a few words in English that contain a "Q" not followed by a "U." Some examples include "qiana," "qwerty," and "tranq," as you mentioned. These words are relatively rare in English, which typically follows the "Q" with a "U." However, many English words with "Q" not followed by "U" are loanwords from other languages. Examples include:

1. **Qat** or **Khat**: A type of plant native to the Horn of Africa and the Arabian Peninsula.
2. **Qi**: A concept from Chinese philosophy meaning "life force" or "vital energy."
3. **Qibla**: The direction that Muslims face when performing prayers, towards the Kaaba in Mecca.

These words have become naturalized in English due to their unique cultural or societal significance.

messages.content: You are Albatross, responding to a user

Persons driving into Canada must have their vehicle's registration document and proof of insurance.
can u drive in canada with us license

Yes, you can drive in Canada with a valid U.S. driver's license. In addition to your driver's license, you'll also need to have your vehicle's registration documents and proof of insurance, as you've mentioned. It's a good idea to check with your insurance provider to ensure your coverage extends to Canada. If you plan to stay or drive in Canada for an extended period, you may want to look into additional requirements or consider obtaining an International Driving Permit (IDP), though it is generally not required for short visits.

samples.input:
The knockout stage of the 2018 FIFA World Cup was the second and final stage of the competition, following the group stage. It began on 30 June with the round of 16 and ended on 15 July with the final match, held at the Luzhniki Stadium in Moscow. The top two teams from each group (16 in total) advanced to the knockout stage to compete in a single-elimination style tournament. A third place play-off was also played between the two losing teams of the semi-finals.
is there a play off for third place in the world cup

messages.content: You are Albatross, responding to a user

The knockout stage of the 2018 FIFA World Cup was the second and final stage of the competition, following the group stage. It began on 30 June with the round of 16 and ended on 15 July with the final match, held at the Luzhniki Stadium in Moscow. The top two teams from each group (16 in total) advanced to the knockout stage to compete in a single-elimination style tournament. A third place play-off was also played between the two losing teams of the semi-finals.
is there a play off for third place in the world cup

Yes, in the FIFA World Cup, there is a third place play-off match. This match is played between the two teams that lost in the semi-finals to determine which team finishes in third place. It takes place the day before the final match of the tournament. This practice has been a part of the World Cup since the inaugural tournament in 1930, with the exception of 1950 when the tournament had a different format.

samples.input:
In response to the National Minimum Drinking Age Act in 1984, which reduced by up to 10% the federal highway funding of any state which did not have a minimum purchasing age of 21, the New York Legislature raised the drinking age from 19 to 21, effective December 1, 1985. (The drinking age had been 18 for many years before the first raise on December 4th, 1982, to 19.) Persons under 21 are prohibited from purchasing alcohol or possessing alcohol with the intent to consume, unless the alcohol was given to that person by their parent or legal guardian. There is no law prohibiting where people under 21 may possess or consume alcohol that was given to them by their parents. Persons under 21 are prohibited from having a blood alcohol level of 0.02% or higher while driving.
can minors drink with parents in new york

Bloodline was announced in October 2014 as part of a partnership between Netflix and Sony Pictures Television, representing Netflix's first major deal with a major film studio for a television series. The series was created and executive produced by Todd A. Kessler, Glenn Kessler, and Daniel Zelman, who previously created the FX series Damages. According to its official synopsis released by Netflix, Bloodline ``centers on a close-knit family of four adult siblings whose secrets and scars are revealed when their black sheep brother returns home.''

samples.input:
Shower gels for men may contain the ingredient menthol, which gives a cooling and stimulating sensation on the skin, and some men's shower gels are also designed specifically for use on hair and body. Shower gels contain milder surfactant bases than shampoos, and some also contain gentle conditioning agents in the formula. This means that shower gels can also double as an effective and perfectly acceptable substitute to shampoo, even if they are not labelled as a hair and body wash. Washing hair with shower gel should give approximately the same result as using a moisturising shampoo.
is it bad to wash your hair with shower gel

messages.content: You are Albatross, responding to a user

Shower gels for men may contain the ingredient menthol, which gives a cooling and stimulating sensation on the skin, and some men's shower gels are also designed specifically for use on hair and body. Shower gels contain milder surfactant bases than shampoos, and some also contain gentle conditioning agents in the formula. This means that shower gels can also double as an effective and perfectly acceptable substitute to shampoo, even if they are not labelled as a hair and body wash. Washing hair with shower gel should give approximately the same result as using a moisturising shampoo.
is it bad to wash your hair with shower gel

Using shower gel to wash your hair occasionally is generally not harmful, but it’s not the most optimal practice for regular hair care. Shower gels and shampoos have different formulations tailored to their specific purposes. While shower gels have milder surfactants than some shampoos and can contain conditioning agents, they are primarily designed to cleanse the skin and might not provide the same benefits or care that a proper shampoo would for your hair and scalp.

Here are a few considerations:

1. **Hair and Scalp Needs:** Shampoos are specifically formulated to address issues related to hair and scalp health, such as removing excess oil, dirt, and product buildup while maintaining proper moisture levels. Shower gels might not be able to address these needs effectively, especially for those with specific hair concerns like dandruff or oily scalp.

2. **pH Levels:** A shampoo is typically formulated with a pH suited for the scalp, whereas a shower gel's pH might not align as well, potentially leading to a dry scalp or dull hair if used frequently.

3. **Hair Conditioning:** Many shampoos are designed to aid in detangling and making hair more manageable. Shower gels might lack these conditioning properties, which could lead to drier or more tangled hair.

As a substitute in a pinch, shower gel can be used, but for optimal hair and scalp health, it's better to use a product specifically designed for hair. If you find yourself frequently using shower gel on your hair, consider investing in a 2-in-1 hair and body wash specifically designed for dual-purpose use.

samples.input:
The liver detoxifies and breaks down chemicals, poisons and other toxins that enter the body. For example, the liver transforms ammonia (which is poisonous) into urea in fish, amphibians and mammals, and into uric acid in birds and reptiles. Urea is filtered by the kidney into urine or through the gills in fish and tadpoles. Uric acid is paste-like and expelled as a semi-solid waste (the ``white'' in bird excrements). The liver also produces bile, and the body uses bile to break down fats into usable fats and unusable waste.
is the liver part of the excretory system

messages.content: You are Albatross, responding to a user

The liver detoxifies and breaks down chemicals, poisons and other toxins that enter the body. For example, the liver transforms ammonia (which is poisonous) into urea in fish, amphibians and mammals, and into uric acid in birds and reptiles. Urea is filtered by the kidney into urine or through the gills in fish and tadpoles. Uric acid is paste-like and expelled as a semi-solid waste (the ``white'' in bird excrements). The liver also produces bile, and the body uses bile to break down fats into usable fats and unusable waste.
is the liver part of the excretory system

Yes, the liver is considered part of the excretory system, though it is not typically highlighted as one of the primary excretory organs like the kidneys. The liver plays a crucial role in detoxification and the metabolism of waste products. It converts harmful substances, such as ammonia, into less toxic forms like urea, which the kidneys can then filter out and eliminate from the body. Additionally, the liver produces bile, which aids in the digestion and excretion of fats. While the kidneys primarily handle excretion, the liver's involvement in detoxification and waste management is essential for maintaining the body's internal balance.

Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them is a 2016 fantasy film directed by David Yates. A joint British and American production, it is a spin-off and prequel to the Harry Potter film series, and it was produced and written by J.K. Rowling in her screenwriting debut, and inspired by her 2001 book of the same name. The film stars Eddie Redmayne as Newt Scamander, with Katherine Waterston, Dan Fogler, Alison Sudol, Ezra Miller, Samantha Morton, Jon Voight, Carmen Ejogo, Ron Perlman, Colin Farrell and Johnny Depp in supporting roles. It is the first installment in the Fantastic Beasts film series, and ninth overall in the Wizarding World franchise, that began with the Harry Potter films.
is fantastic beasts and where to find them a prequel

samples.input:
The Strangers is a 2008 American slasher film written and directed by Bryan Bertino. Kristen (Liv Tyler) and James (Scott Speedman) are expecting a relaxing weekend at a family vacation home, but their stay turns out to be anything but peaceful as three masked torturers leave Kristen and James struggling for survival. Writer-director Bertino was inspired by real-life events: the Manson family Tate murders, a multiple homicide; the Keddie Cabin Murders, that occurred in California in 1981; and a series of break-ins that occurred in his own neighborhood as a child. Made on a budget of $9 million, the film was shot on location in rural South Carolina in the fall of 2006.
was the movie strangers based on a true story

samples.input:
The Resident is an American medical drama television series aired by Fox Broadcasting Company that premiered on January 21, 2018, as a mid-season replacement entry in the 2017--18 television season. The fictional series focuses on the lives and duties of staff members at Chastain Park Memorial Hospital, while delving into the bureaucratic practices of the hospital industry. Formerly called The City, the show was purchased by Fox from Showtime in 2017. It was created by created by Amy Holden Jones, Hayley Schore, and Roshan Sethi. On May 10, 2017, Fox ordered a full 14-episode season and renewed the series for a second season on May 7, 2018. The first season officially concluded on May 14, 2018.
is the tv show the resident over for the season

Magnesium citrate is a magnesium preparation in salt form with citric acid in a 1:1 ratio (1 magnesium atom per citrate molecule). The name ``magnesium citrate'' is ambiguous and sometimes may refer to other salts such as trimagnesium citrate which has a magnesium:citrate ratio of 3:2.
does magnesium citrate have citric acid in it

messages.content: You are Albatross, responding to a user

Magnesium citrate is a magnesium preparation in salt form with citric acid in a 1:1 ratio (1 magnesium atom per citrate molecule). The name ``magnesium citrate'' is ambiguous and sometimes may refer to other salts such as trimagnesium citrate which has a magnesium:citrate ratio of 3:2.
does magnesium citrate have citric acid in it

Magnesium citrate is a compound consisting of magnesium and citrate ions. While it is derived from citric acid, the acid itself is not present in its free form in magnesium citrate. Instead, the citrate part of magnesium citrate is the deprotonated form of citric acid, meaning that magnesium citrate contains citrate ions rather than citric acid.

samples.input:
Street Addressing will have the same street address of the post office, plus a ``unit number'' that matches the P.O. Box number. As an example, in El Centro, California, the post office is located at 1598 Main Street. Therefore, for P.O. Box 9975 (fictitious), the Street Addressing would be: 1598 Main Street Unit 9975, El Centro, CA. Nationally, the first five digits of the zip code may or may not be the same as the P.O. Box address, and the last four digits (Zip + 4) are virtually always different. Except for a few of the largest post offices in the U.S., the 'Street Addressing' (not the P.O. Box address) nine digit Zip + 4 is the same for all boxes at a given location.
does p o box come before street address

messages.content: You are Albatross, responding to a user

Street Addressing will have the same street address of the post office, plus a ``unit number'' that matches the P.O. Box number. As an example, in El Centro, California, the post office is located at 1598 Main Street. Therefore, for P.O. Box 9975 (fictitious), the Street Addressing would be: 1598 Main Street Unit 9975, El Centro, CA. Nationally, the first five digits of the zip code may or may not be the same as the P.O. Box address, and the last four digits (Zip + 4) are virtually always different. Except for a few of the largest post offices in the U.S., the 'Street Addressing' (not the P.O. Box address) nine digit Zip + 4 is the same for all boxes at a given location.
does p o box come before street address

When formatting an address that includes both a street address and a P.O. Box number, the correct order is typically:

1. Recipient's Name
2. Street Address (with "Unit" or "Suite" number if applicable)
3. P.O. Box number
4. City, State, ZIP Code

However, it's important to note that some mailers or recipients may have specific preferences or requirements. It's always a good idea to verify with the intended recipient or the mailing guidelines of the relevant postal service. In the example you provided, for official or formal mailing purposes, you'd generally structure it like this:

[Recipient Name]  
1598 Main Street Unit 9975  
P.O. Box 9975  
El Centro, CA [ZIP Code]

The priority for delivery is typically to the P.O. Box when both an address and a P.O. Box are included, as that's the more specific location for sorting and delivery purposes. However, when using Street Addressing with just a unit number, it usually doesn't include the P.O. Box number in the address. Therefore, it might look like this:

[Recipient Name]  
1598 Main Street Unit 9975  
El Centro, CA [ZIP Code + 4]  

For Street Addressing services, it's often recommended to exclude the P.O. Box number entirely from the address, relying instead on the unit number included in the street address format. Make sure to follow any specific guidelines provided by your local post office for correct addressing.

samples.input:
A spark plug (sometimes, in British English, a sparking plug, and, colloquially, a plug) is a device for delivering electric current from an ignition system to the combustion chamber of a spark-ignition engine to ignite the compressed fuel/air mixture by an electric spark, while containing combustion pressure within the engine. A spark plug has a metal threaded shell, electrically isolated from a central electrode by a porcelain insulator. The central electrode, which may contain a resistor, is connected by a heavily insulated wire to the output terminal of an ignition coil or magneto. The spark plug's metal shell is screwed into the engine's cylinder head and thus electrically grounded. The central electrode protrudes through the porcelain insulator into the combustion chamber, forming one or more spark gaps between the inner end of the central electrode and usually one or more protuberances or structures attached to the inner end of the threaded shell and designated the side, earth, or ground electrode(s).
does a spark plug keep an engine running

messages.content: You are Albatross, responding to a user

A spark plug (sometimes, in British English, a sparking plug, and, colloquially, a plug) is a device for delivering electric current from an ignition system to the combustion chamber of a spark-ignition engine to ignite the compressed fuel/air mixture by an electric spark, while containing combustion pressure within the engine. A spark plug has a metal threaded shell, electrically isolated from a central electrode by a porcelain insulator. The central electrode, which may contain a resistor, is connected by a heavily insulated wire to the output terminal of an ignition coil or magneto. The spark plug's metal shell is screwed into the engine's cylinder head and thus electrically grounded. The central electrode protrudes through the porcelain insulator into the combustion chamber, forming one or more spark gaps between the inner end of the central electrode and usually one or more protuberances or structures attached to the inner end of the threaded shell and designated the side, earth, or ground electrode(s).
does a spark plug keep an engine running

A spark plug plays a crucial role in starting and running an engine, but it does not by itself keep the engine running. It provides the necessary spark to ignite the air-fuel mixture in the combustion chamber of a spark-ignition engine. This ignition is essential for starting the engine and for maintaining continuous combustion cycles while the engine runs.

Once the engine is running, the spark plugs continue to ignite the fuel-air mixture in each cylinder at the appropriate times, as controlled by the ignition system. This process needs to happen repeatedly and reliably to keep the engine running smoothly.

If there's an issue with the spark plugs, such as fouling or wear, it can lead to misfires, reduced engine performance, or even cause the engine to stall. But overall, the spark plugs are just one component of a much larger system that keeps an engine running smoothly.

samples.input:
Ladies may wear a long (over the shoulders or to ankles) cloak usually called a cape, or a full-length cloak. Gentlemen wear an ankle-length or full-length cloak. Formal cloaks often have expensive, colored linings and trimmings such as silk, satin, velvet and fur.
is a cape and a cloak the same

messages.content: You are Albatross, responding to a user

Ladies may wear a long (over the shoulders or to ankles) cloak usually called a cape, or a full-length cloak. Gentlemen wear an ankle-length or full-length cloak. Formal cloaks often have expensive, colored linings and trimmings such as silk, satin, velvet and fur.
is a cape and a cloak the same

A cape and a cloak are similar but distinct garments. Here are some key differences:

1. **Length**:
   - Capes are generally shorter, often ending around the waist, shoulders, or mid-thigh.
   - Cloaks are longer, typically reaching the knees, ankles, or the floor.

2. **Coverage**:
   - Capes provide less coverage, primarily protecting the upper body.
   - Cloaks offer full coverage, enveloping more of the body.

3. **Fastening**:
   - Capes usually fasten around the neck or shoulders.
   - Cloaks may have more elaborate fastening systems, sometimes with ties, clasps, or buttons.

4. **Formal Use**:
   - Cloaks are more commonly associated with formal or ceremonial attire.
   - Capes can be used in both formal settings and as fashion statements or costume elements.

5. **Design**:
   - Capes often have a simpler design and are less voluminous.
   - Cloaks often have a fuller, more flowing design, sometimes with hoods.

While both capes and cloaks are outer garments worn over the shoulders, their differences in length, coverage, and usage set them apart.

1. **Length**:
   - Capes are generally shorter, often ending around the waist, shoulders, or mid-thigh.
   - Cloaks are longer, typically reaching the knees, ankles, or the floor.

2. **Coverage**:
   - Capes provide less coverage, primarily protecting the upper body.
   - Cloaks offer full coverage, enveloping more of the body.

3. **Fastening**:
   - Capes usually fasten around the neck or shoulders.
   - Cloaks may have more elaborate fastening systems, sometimes with ties, clasps, or buttons.

4. **Formal Use**:
   - Cloaks are more commonly associated with formal or ceremonial attire.
   - Capes can be used in both formal settings and as fashion statements or costume elements.

5. **Design**:
   - Capes often have a simpler design and are less voluminous.
   - Cloaks often have a fuller, more flowing design, sometimes with hoods.

While both capes and cloaks are outer garments worn over the shoulders, their differences in length, coverage, and usage set them apart.

Renunciation of U.S. citizenship was free until July 2010, at which time a fee of $450 was established. An increase to $2,350, effective September 12, 2014, was justified as ``reflective of the true cost'' of processing. This followed a fee increase of approximately 220% in 2013. The increase took effect in January 2015.
does it cost money to renounce us citizenship

messages.content: You are Albatross, responding to a user

Renunciation of U.S. citizenship was free until July 2010, at which time a fee of $450 was established. An increase to $2,350, effective September 12, 2014, was justified as ``reflective of the true cost'' of processing. This followed a fee increase of approximately 220% in 2013. The increase took effect in January 2015.
does it cost money to renounce us citizenship

Yes, it does cost money to renounce U.S. citizenship. As of the information you provided, the fee for renunciation was increased to $2,350 in 2014, which was justified as reflecting the true cost of processing the renunciation. This fee is meant to cover the administrative costs associated with processing the renunciation of citizenship. If you're considering renunciation, it's advisable to check the most current fees and procedures with the U.S. Department of State or a U.S. embassy or consulate, as these can change over time.

samples.input:
The Fire Tablet, formerly called the Kindle Fire, is a tablet computer developed by Amazon.com. Built with Quanta Computer, the Kindle Fire was first released in November 2011, featuring a color 7-inch multi-touch display with IPS technology and running a custom version of Google's Android operating system called Fire OS. The Kindle Fire HD followed in September 2012, and the Kindle Fire HDX in September 2013. In September 2014, when the fourth generation was introduced, the name ``Kindle'' was dropped. In September 2015, the fifth generation Fire 7 was released, followed by the sixth generation Fire HD 8, in September 2016. The seventh generation Fire 7 was released in June 2017.
is a fire 7 the same as a kindle

messages.content: You are Albatross, responding to a user

The Fire Tablet, formerly called the Kindle Fire, is a tablet computer developed by Amazon.com. Built with Quanta Computer, the Kindle Fire was first released in November 2011, featuring a color 7-inch multi-touch display with IPS technology and running a custom version of Google's Android operating system called Fire OS. The Kindle Fire HD followed in September 2012, and the Kindle Fire HDX in September 2013. In September 2014, when the fourth generation was introduced, the name ``Kindle'' was dropped. In September 2015, the fifth generation Fire 7 was released, followed by the sixth generation Fire HD 8, in September 2016. The seventh generation Fire 7 was released in June 2017.
is a fire 7 the same as a kindle

The Fire 7 is part of the line of tablets originally known as the Kindle Fire. However, starting with the fourth generation in September 2014, Amazon dropped the "Kindle" name from its tablets and began marketing them simply as "Fire." So, while the Fire 7 is part of the evolution of what was originally the Kindle Fire series, it is not officially called a "Kindle" anymore. Instead, it is just referred to as the Fire 7. The term "Kindle" now generally refers to Amazon's line of e-readers, which are separate from the Fire tablet line.

samples.input:
Contour feathers are not uniformly distributed on the skin of the bird except in some groups such as the penguins, ratites and screamers. In most birds the feathers grow from specific tracts of skin called pterylae; between the pterylae there are regions which are free of feathers called apterylae (or apteria). Filoplumes and down may arise from the apterylae. The arrangement of these feather tracts, pterylosis or pterylography, varies across bird families and has been used in the past as a means for determining the evolutionary relationships of bird families.
do penguins have feathers arising from the epidermis

do penguins have feathers arising from the epidermis

Yes, penguins do have feathers arising from the epidermis. Unlike most birds, where feathers grow primarily from specific tracts called pterylae, penguin feathers are uniformly distributed across their bodies. This dense and uniform feather distribution helps penguins with insulation and waterproofing, key adaptations for their aquatic and often cold environments. Penguins have specialized feathers that are short and overlap tightly to create a waterproof layer over their bodies.

samples.input:
A new engine is broken in by following specific driving guidelines during the first few hours of its use. The focus of breaking in an engine is on the contact between the piston rings of the engine and the cylinder wall. There is no universal preparation or set of instructions for breaking in an engine. Most importantly, experts disagree on whether it is better to start engines on high or low power to break them in. While there are still consequences to an unsuccessful break-in, they are harder to quantify on modern engines than on older models. In general, people no longer break in the engines of their own vehicles after purchasing a car or motorcycle, because the process is done in production. It is still common, even today, to find that an owner's manual recommends gentle use at first (often specified as the first 500 or 1000 kilometres or miles). But it is usually only normal use without excessive demands that is specified, as opposed to light/limited use. For example, the manual will specify that the car be driven normally, but not in excess of the highway speed limit.
do you need to break in a car

messages.content: You are Albatross, responding to a user

A new engine is broken in by following specific driving guidelines during the first few hours of its use. The focus of breaking in an engine is on the contact between the piston rings of the engine and the cylinder wall. There is no universal preparation or set of instructions for breaking in an engine. Most importantly, experts disagree on whether it is better to start engines on high or low power to break them in. While there are still consequences to an unsuccessful break-in, they are harder to quantify on modern engines than on older models. In general, people no longer break in the engines of their own vehicles after purchasing a car or motorcycle, because the process is done in production. It is still common, even today, to find that an owner's manual recommends gentle use at first (often specified as the first 500 or 1000 kilometres or miles). But it is usually only normal use without excessive demands that is specified, as opposed to light/limited use. For example, the manual will specify that the car be driven normally, but not in excess of the highway speed limit.
do you need to break in a car

For most modern vehicles, a specific break-in procedure is often not necessary because manufacturers typically pre-condition the engine at the factory. However, owner’s manuals frequently suggest a gentle use period during the initial 500 to 1,000 miles (or kilometers) to ensure optimal performance and longevity of the engine. This recommendation generally emphasizes normal driving without excessive acceleration, high RPMs, or heavy towing. Following these guidelines can help ensure that the engine components settle properly and potentially extend the vehicle's lifespan. Checking your specific vehicle’s manual for any unique instructions is always a good idea.

samples.input:
On the grounds of the speedway is the Indianapolis Motor Speedway Museum, which opened in 1956, and houses the Auto Racing Hall of Fame. The museum moved into its current building located in the infield in 1976. Also on the grounds is the Brickyard Crossing Golf Resort, which originally opened as the Speedway Golf Course in 1929. The golf course has 14 holes outside the track, along the backstretch, and four holes in the infield. The speedway also served as the venue for the opening ceremonies for the 1987 Pan American Games.

samples.input:
As part of Marvel's Marvel NOW! initiative a new Deadpool ongoing series was launched, written by Brian Posehn and Gerry Duggan and illustrated by Tony Moore. He is also a member of the Thunderbolts. In the 27th issue of his new series, as part of ``All-New Marvel NOW!'', Deadpool was married for the third time. Initially a secret, his bride was revealed in the webcomic Deadpool: The Gauntlet to be Shiklah, Queen of the Undead. Deadpool also discovers that he has a daughter by the name of Eleanor from a former flame of Deadpool named Carmelita.
does deadpool have a kid in the comics

samples.input:
The Commonwealth government has its own tax laws and Puerto Ricans are also required to pay some US federal taxes, although most residents do not have to pay the federal personal income tax. In 2009, Puerto Rico paid $3.742 billion into the US Treasury. Residents of Puerto Rico pay into Social Security, and are thus eligible for Social Security benefits upon retirement. However, they are excluded from the Supplemental Security Income.
is federal income tax the same as social security

messages.content: You are Albatross, responding to a user

The Commonwealth government has its own tax laws and Puerto Ricans are also required to pay some US federal taxes, although most residents do not have to pay the federal personal income tax. In 2009, Puerto Rico paid $3.742 billion into the US Treasury. Residents of Puerto Rico pay into Social Security, and are thus eligible for Social Security benefits upon retirement. However, they are excluded from the Supplemental Security Income.
is federal income tax the same as social security

No, federal income tax and Social Security are not the same. Federal income tax is a tax levied by the U.S. government on the annual earnings of individuals, corporations, trusts, and other legal entities. The amount of federal income tax you pay is based on your income level and filing status.

Social Security, on the other hand, is a separate system funded by payroll taxes under the Federal Insurance Contributions Act (FICA). These taxes are specifically earmarked to fund Social Security benefits, which provide financial assistance to retirees, disabled individuals, and survivors of deceased workers.

While residents of Puerto Rico typically do not pay federal personal income tax, they do pay into Social Security and are eligible for its benefits upon retirement. However, Puerto Ricans are excluded from receiving Supplemental Security Income (SSI), which is a needs-based program for elderly, blind, or disabled individuals with limited income and resources.

samples.input:
The crank sensor can be used in combination with a similar camshaft position sensor to monitor the relationship between the pistons and valves in the engine, which is particularly important in engines with variable valve timing. This method is also used to ``synchronise'' a four stroke engine upon starting, allowing the management system to know when to inject the fuel. It is also commonly used as the primary source for the measurement of engine speed in revolutions per minute.
is an engine speed sensor the same as a crankshaft sensor

messages.content: You are Albatross, responding to a user

The crank sensor can be used in combination with a similar camshaft position sensor to monitor the relationship between the pistons and valves in the engine, which is particularly important in engines with variable valve timing. This method is also used to ``synchronise'' a four stroke engine upon starting, allowing the management system to know when to inject the fuel. It is also commonly used as the primary source for the measurement of engine speed in revolutions per minute.
is an engine speed sensor the same as a crankshaft sensor

Yes, an engine speed sensor is often the same as a crankshaft sensor. The crankshaft sensor monitors the position and rotational speed of the crankshaft, which is used to determine engine speed in revolutions per minute (RPM). This information is crucial for engine management systems to make decisions about fuel injection and ignition timing. While there are specific sensors dedicated to measuring engine speed, in many contexts, the crankshaft sensor serves this purpose.

samples.input:
Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom is a 1984 American action-adventure film directed by Steven Spielberg. It is the second installment in the Indiana Jones franchise and a prequel to the 1981 film Raiders of the Lost Ark, featuring Harrison Ford reprising his role as the title character. After arriving in North India, Indiana Jones is asked by desperate villagers to find a mystical stone and rescue their children from a Thuggee cult practicing child slavery, black magic and ritual human sacrifice in honor of the goddess Kali.
is indiana jones temple of doom a prequel

messages.content: You are Albatross, responding to a user

Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom is a 1984 American action-adventure film directed by Steven Spielberg. It is the second installment in the Indiana Jones franchise and a prequel to the 1981 film Raiders of the Lost Ark, featuring Harrison Ford reprising his role as the title character. After arriving in North India, Indiana Jones is asked by desperate villagers to find a mystical stone and rescue their children from a Thuggee cult practicing child slavery, black magic and ritual human sacrifice in honor of the goddess Kali.
is indiana jones temple of doom a prequel

Yes, "Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom" is a prequel to "Raiders of the Lost Ark." Although it was released in 1984, three years after "Raiders of the Lost Ark," the events in "Temple of Doom" are set in 1935, one year before the events of "Raiders of the Lost Ark," which is set in 1936.

The untitled Avengers film, colloquially referred to as Avengers 4, is an upcoming American superhero film based on the Marvel Comics superhero team the Avengers, produced by Marvel Studios and distributed by Walt Disney Studios Motion Pictures. It is intended to be the direct sequel to 2018's Avengers: Infinity War, as well as the sequel to 2012's Marvel's The Avengers and 2015's Avengers: Age of Ultron and the twenty-second film in the Marvel Cinematic Universe (MCU). The film is directed by Anthony and Joe Russo, with a screenplay by the writing team of Christopher Markus and Stephen McFeely, and features an ensemble cast with many actors from previous MCU films.

samples.input:
Announced in April 2000 at the New York Auto Show and arriving in late 2000 in Japan and January 2001 in North America, the Highlander became one of the first car-based mid-size SUV or mid-size crossovers. The Highlander is the crossover counterpart to the more rugged, truck-based midsize 4Runner and became Toyota's best-selling SUV before being surpassed by the smaller RAV4 in 2006. In Japan, the Kluger is exclusive to dealership network called Toyota NETZ as a larger alternative to the RAV4.
is the toyota highlander on a truck frame

messages.content: You are Albatross, responding to a user

Announced in April 2000 at the New York Auto Show and arriving in late 2000 in Japan and January 2001 in North America, the Highlander became one of the first car-based mid-size SUV or mid-size crossovers. The Highlander is the crossover counterpart to the more rugged, truck-based midsize 4Runner and became Toyota's best-selling SUV before being surpassed by the smaller RAV4 in 2006. In Japan, the Kluger is exclusive to dealership network called Toyota NETZ as a larger alternative to the RAV4.
is the toyota highlander on a truck frame

No, the Toyota Highlander is not built on a truck frame. It is built on a unibody platform, which is more car-like. This distinguishes it from more traditional SUVs like the Toyota 4Runner, which is built on a body-on-frame design, typical of trucks. The Highlander's unibody construction contributes to a smoother ride and better fuel efficiency, making it a popular choice among mid-size crossovers.

samples.input:
Since the Copyright Act of 1909, United States musicians have had the right to record a version of someone else's previously recorded and released tune, whether it is music alone or music with lyrics. A license can be negotiated between representatives of the interpreting artist and the copyright holder, or recording published tunes can fall under a mechanical license whereby the recording artist pays a standard royalty to the original author/copyright holder through an organization such as the Harry Fox Agency, and is safe under copyright law even if they do not have any permission from the original author. A similar service was provided by Limelight by RightsFlow, until January 2015, when they announced they will be closing their service. The U.S. Congress introduced the mechanical license to head off an attempt by the Aeolian Company to monopolize the piano roll market.
is it legal to do a cover of a song

messages.content: You are Albatross, responding to a user

Since the Copyright Act of 1909, United States musicians have had the right to record a version of someone else's previously recorded and released tune, whether it is music alone or music with lyrics. A license can be negotiated between representatives of the interpreting artist and the copyright holder, or recording published tunes can fall under a mechanical license whereby the recording artist pays a standard royalty to the original author/copyright holder through an organization such as the Harry Fox Agency, and is safe under copyright law even if they do not have any permission from the original author. A similar service was provided by Limelight by RightsFlow, until January 2015, when they announced they will be closing their service. The U.S. Congress introduced the mechanical license to head off an attempt by the Aeolian Company to monopolize the piano roll market.
is it legal to do a cover of a song

Yes, it is generally legal to record and release a cover of a song in the United States, thanks to the provisions introduced with the Copyright Act. When you record a cover, you typically need to obtain a mechanical license, which allows you to legally reproduce and distribute the musical composition. This type of license can be acquired through agencies like the Harry Fox Agency.

A mechanical license grants you the right to cover the song without needing the original author's explicit permission, provided you pay the required royalties to the copyright holder. These licenses are intended to ensure that the original creators are compensated while allowing new artists to interpret existing works.

It's important to note that while covering a song is legal with the appropriate license, there are still limitations regarding how the song is used. For example, if you want to use the cover in a film, advertisement, or other audiovisual projects, you may need additional synchronization licenses. It's always a good practice to ensure you have all the necessary permissions and licenses for your specific use case.

samples.input:
The carbon-hydrogen bond (C--H bond) is a bond between carbon and hydrogen atoms that can be found in many organic compounds. This bond is a covalent bond meaning that carbon shares its outer valence electrons with up to four hydrogens. This completes both of their outer shells making them stable. Carbon--hydrogen bonds have a bond length of about 1.09 Å (1.09 × 10 m) and a bond energy of about 413 kJ/mol (see table below). Using Pauling's scale--C (2.55) and H (2.2)--the electronegativity difference between these two atoms is 0.35. Because of this small difference in electronegativities, the C−H bond is generally regarded as being non-polar. In structural formulas of molecules, the hydrogen atoms are often omitted. Compound classes consisting solely of C--H bonds and C--C bonds are alkanes, alkenes, alkynes, and aromatic hydrocarbons. Collectively they are known as hydrocarbons.
can carbon form polar covalent bonds with hydrogen

messages.content: You are Albatross, responding to a user

The carbon-hydrogen bond (C--H bond) is a bond between carbon and hydrogen atoms that can be found in many organic compounds. This bond is a covalent bond meaning that carbon shares its outer valence electrons with up to four hydrogens. This completes both of their outer shells making them stable. Carbon--hydrogen bonds have a bond length of about 1.09 Å (1.09 × 10 m) and a bond energy of about 413 kJ/mol (see table below). Using Pauling's scale--C (2.55) and H (2.2)--the electronegativity difference between these two atoms is 0.35. Because of this small difference in electronegativities, the C−H bond is generally regarded as being non-polar. In structural formulas of molecules, the hydrogen atoms are often omitted. Compound classes consisting solely of C--H bonds and C--C bonds are alkanes, alkenes, alkynes, and aromatic hydrocarbons. Collectively they are known as hydrocarbons.
can carbon form polar covalent bonds with hydrogen

The carbon-hydrogen (C–H) bond is generally considered non-polar because the difference in electronegativity between carbon (2.55) and hydrogen (2.20) is relatively small at 0.35. This small difference doesn't result in a significant polarity, meaning that the electrons are shared relatively equally between the carbon and hydrogen atoms.

However, it's essential to note that while the individual C–H bond is considered non-polar, the overall polarity of a molecule depends on its entire structure, including other atoms and the shape of the molecule. For instance, in a larger organic compound, C–H bonds might still contribute to the overall distribution of electron density and influence the molecule's dipole moment, but they do so subtly compared to other, more polar bonds (like O–H or C–O).

In summary, carbon does not form polar covalent bonds with hydrogen due to their similar electronegativities. However, the entire molecule's structure and other more polar bonds can influence the overall polarity of the compound.

is there a sequel to the movie the golden compass

messages.content: You are Albatross, responding to a user

In 2011, Philip Pullman remarked at the British Humanist Association annual conference that due to the first film's disappointing sales in the United States, there would not be any sequels made.
is there a sequel to the movie the golden compass

No, there wasn't a sequel made to the movie "The Golden Compass." The film, released in 2007, was based on the first book of Philip Pullman's "His Dark Materials" series. While it performed reasonably well internationally, it underperformed at the U.S. box office, leading to the cancellation of plans to produce sequels adapting the subsequent books in the series. However, the entire trilogy has since been adapted into a television series by HBO and BBC, which started airing in 2019.

samples.input:
Columbus Day is a national holiday in many countries of the Americas and elsewhere which officially celebrates the anniversary of Christopher Columbus's arrival in the Americas on October 12, 1492. The landing is celebrated as ``Columbus Day'' in the United States, as ``Día de la Raza'' (``Day of the Race'') in some countries in Latin America, as ``Día de la Hispanidad'' and ``Fiesta Nacional'' in Spain, where it is also the religious festivity of la Virgen del Pilar, as Día de las Américas (Day of the Americas) in Belize and Uruguay, as Día del Respeto a la Diversidad Cultural (Day of Respect for Cultural Diversity) in Argentina, and as Giornata Nazionale di Cristoforo Colombo or Festa Nazionale di Cristoforo Colombo in Italy as well as in Little Italys around the world. As the day of remembrance of Our Lady of the Pillar, 12 October had been declared a religious feast day throughout the Spanish Empire in 1730; the secular Fiesta de la Raza Española was first proposed by Faustino Rodríguez-San Pedro y Díaz-Argüelles in 1913. In recent years, celebration of the holiday has faced some opposition from various organizations.
is columbus day a national holiday in the united states

messages.content: You are Albatross, responding to a user

Columbus Day is a national holiday in many countries of the Americas and elsewhere which officially celebrates the anniversary of Christopher Columbus's arrival in the Americas on October 12, 1492. The landing is celebrated as ``Columbus Day'' in the United States, as ``Día de la Raza'' (``Day of the Race'') in some countries in Latin America, as ``Día de la Hispanidad'' and ``Fiesta Nacional'' in Spain, where it is also the religious festivity of la Virgen del Pilar, as Día de las Américas (Day of the Americas) in Belize and Uruguay, as Día del Respeto a la Diversidad Cultural (Day of Respect for Cultural Diversity) in Argentina, and as Giornata Nazionale di Cristoforo Colombo or Festa Nazionale di Cristoforo Colombo in Italy as well as in Little Italys around the world. As the day of remembrance of Our Lady of the Pillar, 12 October had been declared a religious feast day throughout the Spanish Empire in 1730; the secular Fiesta de la Raza Española was first proposed by Faustino Rodríguez-San Pedro y Díaz-Argüelles in 1913. In recent years, celebration of the holiday has faced some opposition from various organizations.
is columbus day a national holiday in the united states

Yes, Columbus Day is a federal holiday in the United States, observed on the second Monday of October. It marks the anniversary of Christopher Columbus's arrival in the Americas on October 12, 1492. However, it's worth noting that the celebration of Columbus Day has become controversial, as many people criticize it for ignoring the impact of colonization on Indigenous peoples. As a result, some states and cities in the U.S. have opted to celebrate Indigenous Peoples' Day instead, on the same day as Columbus Day.

As a result, some states and cities in the U.S. have opted to celebrate Indigenous Peoples' Day instead, on the same day as Columbus Day.

New Balance maintains a manufacturing presence in the United States, as well as in the United Kingdom for the European market, where they produce some of their most popular models such as the 990 model--in contrast to its competitors, which often manufacture exclusively outside the USA and Europe. As a result, New Balance shoes tend to be more expensive than those of many other manufacturers. To offset this pricing difference, New Balance claims to differentiate their products with technical features, such as blended gel inserts, heel counters and a greater selection of sizes, particularly for very narrow and/or very wide widths. The company has made total profits of approximately $69 billion since 1992. They are the second most-renown American sporting company, after Nike.
are new balance and nike the same company

samples.input:
U.S. Highway 20 (US 20) is an east--west United States highway that stretches from the Pacific Northwest all the way to New England. The ``0'' in its route number indicates that US 20 is a coast-to-coast route. Spanning 3,365 miles (5,415 km), it is the longest road in the United States, and particularly from Idaho to Massachusetts, the route roughly parallels that of Interstate 90 (I-90), which is in turn the longest Interstate Highway in the U.S. There is a discontinuity in the official designation of US 20 through Yellowstone National Park, with unnumbered roads used to traverse the park.
is there an interstate that goes coast to coast

messages.content: You are Albatross, responding to a user

U.S. Highway 20 (US 20) is an east--west United States highway that stretches from the Pacific Northwest all the way to New England. The ``0'' in its route number indicates that US 20 is a coast-to-coast route. Spanning 3,365 miles (5,415 km), it is the longest road in the United States, and particularly from Idaho to Massachusetts, the route roughly parallels that of Interstate 90 (I-90), which is in turn the longest Interstate Highway in the U.S. There is a discontinuity in the official designation of US 20 through Yellowstone National Park, with unnumbered roads used to traverse the park.
is there an interstate that goes coast to coast

Yes, there are several Interstate Highways in the United States that span coast to coast. One of the most notable is Interstate 10 (I-10), which runs from Santa Monica, California, to Jacksonville, Florida, covering approximately 2,460 miles. Another is Interstate 80 (I-80), which stretches from San Francisco, California, to Teaneck, New Jersey, covering about 2,900 miles. Additionally, Interstate 90 (I-90) is the longest Interstate Highway, running from Seattle, Washington, to Boston, Massachusetts, for about 3,020 miles. These highways are integral parts of the U.S. Interstate System and connect various regions across the country.

samples.input:
Tomato purée is a thick liquid made by cooking and straining tomatoes. The difference between tomato paste, tomato purée, and tomato sauce is consistency; tomato puree has a thicker consistency and a deeper flavour than sauce.
is pureed tomatoes the same as tomato sauce

messages.content: You are Albatross, responding to a user

Tomato purée is a thick liquid made by cooking and straining tomatoes. The difference between tomato paste, tomato purée, and tomato sauce is consistency; tomato puree has a thicker consistency and a deeper flavour than sauce.
is pureed tomatoes the same as tomato sauce

No, pureed tomatoes and tomato sauce are not the same, although they are similar. Pureed tomatoes are simply tomatoes that have been cooked briefly and then strained to remove skins and seeds, resulting in a smooth, thick liquid. Tomato sauce, on the other hand, typically involves additional ingredients such as herbs, spices, onions, garlic, or other flavorings, and it is usually cooked longer to develop its flavor. Tomato sauce is also thinner than tomato puree and has more complex flavors due to these added ingredients.

Tomato sauce is also thinner than tomato puree and has more complex flavors due to these added ingredients.

English orthography typically represents vowel sounds with the five conventional vowel letters ⟨a, e, i, o, u⟩, as well as ⟨y⟩, which may also be a consonant depending on context. However, outside of abbreviations, there are a handful of words in English that do not have vowels, either because the vowel sounds are not written with vowel letters or because the words themselves are pronounced without vowel sounds.
can there be a word without a vowel

messages.content: You are Albatross, responding to a user

English orthography typically represents vowel sounds with the five conventional vowel letters ⟨a, e, i, o, u⟩, as well as ⟨y⟩, which may also be a consonant depending on context. However, outside of abbreviations, there are a handful of words in English that do not have vowels, either because the vowel sounds are not written with vowel letters or because the words themselves are pronounced without vowel sounds.
can there be a word without a vowel

Yes, there are words in English that don't use the conventional vowel letters (a, e, i, o, u) or rely on "y" to represent a vowel sound. These words often come from onomatopoeia, borrowed terms, or specific contexts. 

Examples include:

1. **Cwm** - A term of Welsh origin meaning a valley or basin shaped by glaciers.
2. **Crwth** - A Welsh word for an ancient type of stringed instrument.

In these cases, "w" functions as a vowel, representing a similar sound to "oo" in some dialects. Additionally, there are words where "y" serves as a vowel, such as in "myth" or "rhythm," where it takes on the role of representing vowel sounds.

samples.input:
Tipping Point is a British television game show which began airing on ITV on 2 July 2012, and is presented by Ben Shephard. Four contestants answer general knowledge questions to win counters which they use on a large coin pusher arcade-style machine. Only the winner at the end has a chance to take home any money; the others leave with nothing except any non-cash prizes they may have won during the game.

samples.input:
The turkey vulture (Cathartes aura), also known in some North American regions as the turkey buzzard (or just buzzard), and in some areas of the Caribbean as the John crow or carrion crow, is the most widespread of the New World vultures. One of three species in the genus Cathartes of the family Cathartidae, the turkey vulture ranges from southern Canada to the southernmost tip of South America. It inhabits a variety of open and semi-open areas, including subtropical forests, shrublands, pastures, and deserts.
is there such a thing as a turkey vulture

messages.content: You are Albatross, responding to a user

The turkey vulture (Cathartes aura), also known in some North American regions as the turkey buzzard (or just buzzard), and in some areas of the Caribbean as the John crow or carrion crow, is the most widespread of the New World vultures. It inhabits a variety of open and semi-open areas, including subtropical forests, shrublands, pastures, and deserts.
is there such a thing as a turkey vulture

Yes, the turkey vulture (Cathartes aura) is a real bird species. It is the most widespread among the New World vultures and is found across a vast range extending from southern Canada all the way to the southernmost parts of South America. Turkey vultures are known for their adaptability to various environments, including subtropical forests, shrublands, pastures, and deserts. They are recognizable by their large wingspan, dark plumage, and distinctive red head. As scavengers, turkey vultures primarily feed on carrion, using their keen sense of smell to locate food.

samples.input:
As of October 2008, a condor (four under par) hole-in-one on a par 5 hole had been recorded on four occasions, aided by thin air at high altitude, or by cutting the corner on a doglegged or horseshoe-shaped hole. A horseshoe-shaped par 5 hole once enabled a condor hole in one to be achieved with a 3-iron club. The longest recorded straight drive hole-in-one is believed to be 517 yards or 473 metres, on the par 5 No. 9 hole at Green Valley Ranch Golf Club in Denver in 2002, aided by the thin air due to the high altitude. None of these four par 5 holes-in-one were achieved during a professional tournament. A condor is also known as a double albatross, or a triple eagle.
has anyone hit a hole in one on a par 5

samples.input:
MetLife Stadium is an American sports stadium located in East Rutherford, New Jersey, 8 miles outside of New York City. It is part of the Meadowlands Sports Complex and serves as the home stadium for two National Football League (NFL) franchises: the New York Giants and the New York Jets. The stadium is owned by the MetLife Stadium Company, a joint venture of the Giants and Jets, who jointly built the stadium using private funds on land owned by the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority. The stadium opened as New Meadowlands Stadium in 2010. In 2011, MetLife, an insurance company based in New York City, acquired the naming rights to the stadium. At a construction cost of approximately $1.6 billion, it was the most expensive stadium ever built, at the time it opened, and is the second-largest stadium in the NFL in terms of seating capacity.
do the jets and giants share a stadium

messages.content: You are Albatross, responding to a user

do the jets and giants share a stadium

Yes, the New York Jets and the New York Giants share a stadium. Both teams use MetLife Stadium as their home field. This arrangement is somewhat unique in the NFL, as most teams have their own dedicated stadiums. The Jets and Giants, however, have shared a stadium since they both played at the Giants Stadium prior to moving to MetLife Stadium in 2010.

samples.input:
Many martial arts employ the use of common objects as weapons; Filipino martial arts such as Eskrima include practice with machetes, canes, bamboo spears, and knives as a result of the 333 year Spanish colonization that took place in the Philippines which prohibited the ownership and use of standard swords and bladed weapons; Chinese martial arts and some Korean martial arts commonly feature the use of improvised weapons such as fans, hammers and staves. There are even some western martial arts that are based on improvised weapons such as British quarterstaff fighting and Irish stick fighting.
can a hammer be used as a weapon

messages.content: You are Albatross, responding to a user

Many martial arts employ the use of common objects as weapons; Filipino martial arts such as Eskrima include practice with machetes, canes, bamboo spears, and knives as a result of the 333 year Spanish colonization that took place in the Philippines which prohibited the ownership and use of standard swords and bladed weapons; Chinese martial arts and some Korean martial arts commonly feature the use of improvised weapons such as fans, hammers and staves. There are even some western martial arts that are based on improvised weapons such as British quarterstaff fighting and Irish stick fighting.
can a hammer be used as a weapon

Yes, a hammer can definitely be used as a weapon. In martial arts, the concept of using everyday objects for self-defense is quite common, and the hammer, with its solid construction and versatile design, can be particularly effective in this role. 

Its heavy head makes it suitable for delivering powerful strikes, while the handle allows for a firm grip, enabling both swinging and thrusting motions. Traditionally, hammers may not be a standard part of weapon training, but their practicality as an improvised weapon is acknowledged in various martial arts systems.

That said, using a hammer as a weapon should always be seen as a last resort in a self-defense situation, as it can cause significant injury. In self-defense scenarios, the goal is often to neutralize a threat with minimal harm, so appropriate and legal responses should be considered. Legal implications and the context of self-defense should always be kept in mind if one finds themselves considering the use of a hammer or any improvised weapon.

samples.input:
Fox hunting with hounds, as a formalised activity, originated in England in the sixteenth century, in a form very similar to that practised until February 2005, when a law banning the activity in England and Wales came into force. A ban on hunting in Scotland had been passed in 2002, but it continues to be within the law in Northern Ireland and several other countries, including Australia, Canada, France, Ireland and the United States. In Australia, the term also refers to the hunting of foxes with firearms, similar to deer hunting. In much of the world, hunting in general is understood to relate to any game animals or weapons (e.g., deer hunting with bow and arrow); in Britain and Ireland, ``hunting'' without qualification implies fox hunting (or other forms of hunting with hounds--beagling, drag hunting, hunting the clean boot, mink hunting, or stag hunting), as described here.
do they still have fox hunts in england

messages.content: You are Albatross, responding to a user

Fox hunting with hounds, as a formalised activity, originated in England in the sixteenth century, in a form very similar to that practised until February 2005, when a law banning the activity in England and Wales came into force. A ban on hunting in Scotland had been passed in 2002, but it continues to be within the law in Northern Ireland and several other countries, including Australia, Canada, France, Ireland and the United States. In Australia, the term also refers to the hunting of foxes with firearms, similar to deer hunting. In much of the world, hunting in general is understood to relate to any game animals or weapons (e.g., deer hunting with bow and arrow); in Britain and Ireland, ``hunting'' without qualification implies fox hunting (or other forms of hunting with hounds--beagling, drag hunting, hunting the clean boot, mink hunting, or stag hunting), as described here.
do they still have fox hunts in england

As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, traditional fox hunting with hounds is banned in England and Wales under the Hunting Act 2004, which came into effect in February 2005. The act prohibits the hunting of wild mammals with dogs, though there are some exceptions and loopholes, such as trail hunting, where hounds follow an artificially laid scent trail. This is sometimes used as a cover for illegal fox hunting and has been a subject of controversy and debate.

Despite the ban, some hunts have continued to operate by adapting to the legal limitations, either by participating in trail hunting or using other methods within the law. Monitoring and enforcement of the ban can be challenging, and instances of illegal hunting have occasionally been reported.

In summary, while traditional fox hunting as it was historically practiced is illegal in England, some forms of hunting activities continue, often sparking debate and scrutiny regarding their compliance with the law.

samples.input:
The ASU includes a midnight blue coat and low waist trousers for male soldiers; and a midnight blue coat, slacks and skirt for female soldiers. The fabric for the ASU is heavier and more wrinkle resistant than previously manufactured uniforms and will consist of 55% wool and 45% polyester material. The ASU coat has a tailored, athletic cut to improve uniform fit and appearance. The ASU includes an improved heavier and wrinkle resistant short and long-sleeved white shirt with permanent military creases and shoulder loops. The JROTC version replaces the white shirt with the prototype grey shirt and gold braid is not worn on the blue trousers or on the sleeves of the class A coat. Compared to the Army's previous uniforms, the ASU does not include a garrison cap; soldiers will continue to wear the Army's berets.

samples.input:
In the third season, Damon helps Elena in bringing his brother, Stefan, back to Mystic Falls after Stefan becomes Klaus' henchman. The arrangement transpired after a bargain for his blood that would cure Damon of the werewolf bite he had received from Tyler. At first, he is reluctant to involve Elena in the rescue attempts, employing Alaric Saltzman, Elena's guardian, instead as Klaus does not know that Elena is alive after the sacrifice which frees Klaus' hybrid side. However, Elena involves herself, desperate to find Stefan. Damon, though hesitant at first, is unable to refuse her because of his love for her. He also points out to her that she once turned back from finding Stefan since she knew Damon would be in danger, clearly showing that she also has feelings for him. He tells her that ``when (he) drag(s) (his) brother from the edge to deliver him back to (her), (he) wants her to remember the things (she) felt while he was gone.'' When Stefan finally returns to Mystic Falls, his attitude is different from that of the first and second seasons. This causes a rift between Elena and Stefan whereas the relationship between Damon and Elena becomes closer and more intimate. A still loyal Elena, however, refuses to admit her feelings for Damon. In 'Dangerous Liaisons', Elena, frustrated with her feelings for him, tells Damon that his love for her may be a problem, and that this could be causing all their troubles. This incenses Damon, causing him to revert to the uncaring and reckless Damon seen in the previous seasons. The rocky relationship between the two continues until the sexual tension hits the fan and in a moment of heated passion, Elena -- for the first time in the three seasons -- kisses Damon of her own accord. This kiss finally causes Elena to admit that she loves both brothers and realize that she must ultimately make her choice as her own ancestress, Katherine Pierce, who turned the brothers, once did. In assessment of her feelings for Damon, she states this: ``Damon just sort of snuck up on me. He got under my skin and no matter what I do, I can't shake him.'' In the season finale, a trip designed to get her to safety forces Elena to make her choice: to go to Damon and possibly see him one last time; or to go to Stefan and her friends and see them one last time. She chooses the latter when she calls Damon to tell him her decision. Damon, who is trying to stop Alaric, accepts what she says and she tells him that maybe if she had met Damon before she had met Stefan, her choice may have been different. This statement causes Damon to remember the first night he did meet Elena which was, in fact, the night her parents died - before she had met Stefan. Not wanting anyone to know he was in town and after giving her some advice about life and love, Damon compels her to forget. He remembers this as he fights Alaric and seems accepting of his death when Alaric, whose life line is tied to Elena's, suddenly collapses in his arms. Damon is grief-stricken, knowing that this means that Elena has also died and yells, ``No! You are not dead!'' A heartbroken Damon then goes to the hospital demanding to see Elena when the doctor, Meredith Fell, tells him that she gave Elena vampire blood. The last shot of the season finale episode shows Elena in transition.
does damon and elena get together in season 3
